oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Off to Hollywood
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Presley, Elvis; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Rock and roll king Elvis Presley waved goodby to about 200 Memphis fans last night just before leaving for the nation's film capital to star in a movie, 'G. I. Blues.' Nine friends accompanied him in a Missouri Pacific private car which cost the singer $2,424.41. Hollywood will greet him Wednesday." NOTE: Clipping mounted to card stock.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elvis at the Fairgrounds
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Presley, Elvis; Fairgrounds Amusement Park; roller coasters; ferris wheels; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "ROLLIN' ON THE ROCKET - Rock and roll king Elvis Presley hugged singer Anita Wood close early yesterday on a slinging ride called 'The Rocket' at the Fairgrounds Amusement Park in an after-midnight fun spree. Elvis rented the park from 1 a.m. to 5 a.m. and invited about 75 friends to help him kick up his heels." NOTE: Clippings mounted on card stock.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The King Becomes a Tennessee Colonel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Presley, Elvis; Tennessee General Assembly; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Rock-and-roll king Elvis Presley attracted the largest crowd of the session yesterday when he appeared before the Tennessee Legislature. Gov. Buford Ellington, between screams from girls in the gallery, made Elvis a Tennessee colonel. Presley talked briefly, but said he wasn't allowed to sing because of contract commitments." oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elvis honored by Jaycees
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Presley, Elvis; Jaycees; Bush, George H. W.; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In sartorial splendor, with diamond rings on all fingers of his left hand, Elvis Presley accepts an award as one of the National Jaycees' 10 Most Outstanding Young Men in America. The Jaycees wound up their national congress over the weekend. Each recipient of the award made public comments and answered questions in private on subjects of special interest to the Jaycees. Principal address at the awards luncheon was given by UN Ambassador-appointee George Bush, who called upon all Americans to 'work within the system' while advocating new ideas and 'never resort to violence.'" NOTE: Clipping mounted to card stock.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frank M. Harris Memorial Lodge
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Rhodes College; education; universities; 1920s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An early photo of one of the seven original buildings on the Rhodes College campus. It was originally the home of campus engineer John Rollow and his family. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blair T. Hunt
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: education; Hunt, Blair T.; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oral History taping session with Blair T. Hunt, retired high school principal, Mrs. Alma Booth, immediate past president of Memphis Links, Inc., and librarian Ron Walter, Memphis/Shelby County Public Library and Information Center. Links donated to the library tapes of memories from 3 prominent black Memphis educators and a black chairman of the board of a Memphis bank. In addition, 40 historical photographs were included in the presentation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Auditorium Dedication Booklet
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; Ellis Auditorium; entertainment; music; theater; 1920s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The program booklet from the week of the Memphis Auditorium's dedication. The formal dedication took place on October 18, 1924 at the Municipal Market. On October 17th, John Philip Sousa and his band played the opening concert. October 20-22 featured performances by the San Carlo Grand Opera Company with the Pavley-Oukrainsky Ballet Russe ("Company of One hundred and twenty-five Augmented Cast and Orchestra"). The cover also lists Chas. O. Pfeil and George Awsumb as architects of the building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Open Air Theatre 1946 Season Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; entertainment; Memphis Open Air Theatre; music; Overton Park; parks; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The cover of the program for the 1946 season of the Memphis Open Air Theatre. The cover includes a message from Mayor Walter Chandler: "Dear Patron, If you will ask your friends and acquaintances to patronize the Memphis Open Air Theatre, you will do them and the entire City a favor. The MOAT is provided for your wholesome recreation and entertainment, and the larger the attendance at the Shows, the greater will be the success of this public service."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Clement Names Negro Attorney To New Court"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; civil rights; Clement, Frank; Hooks, Benjamin L.; law; Shelby County Criminal Court; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Ben L. Hooks, Negro attorney and minister, yesterday was appointed by Gov. Frank G. Clement as judge of the newly-created Division IV of Shelby County Criminal Court. The post will be the highest judicial position ever attained by a Negro in Tennessee. Dr. Robert White, state historian in Nashville, said no Negro reached a post this high during the Reconstruction era. Mr. Hooks, 40, said yesterday he will accept the appointment, effective Sept. 1... 'All I could say is I do think it is a great advancement for me personally, but more for the race,' Mr. Hooks said."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nurses' Hemlines
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; Methodist Hospital School of Nursing; nursing; women; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "YO-YO HEMLINES were out and no options allowed for students at Methodist Hospital School of Nursing in 1928. This photo, which recently was found at the hospital, shows the 54 students that fall wearing uniforms in the midi-length - a word which was unheard of in that era and had to wait another 40-plus years to be coined by fashion authorities. Except for one nonconformist, all wore the regulation black stockings that were characteristic of the modesty of that time. All the would-be Florence Nightingales who posed on the hospital lawn were stiffly starched, with caps at a primary proper angle and hemlines an unvarying 9 inches from the ground. This might have been more becoming for a tall girl and less so for a short one, but the physique of the wearer was not taken into consideration. 'The rigid regulation,' said Las Savell, director of public relations for the hospital, 'stipulated the hemline had to be exactly 9 inches from the ground, whether the student wore flat heels or Cuban heels.'"
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Memphis - Methodist Hospital - School of Nursing, 1928
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First woman intern at the General Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: General Hospital; Hefley, Martha Lou; medicine; women; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "50 YEARS AGO - Dec. 9, 1934 - For the first time since the General Hospital was founded in 1898, a woman intern will tread the halls of the institution in the line of duty. Next April 1, following her graduation from the University of Tennessee, pretty 22-year-old Martha Lou Hefley will drop the 'Miss' from her name to become Dr. Hefley. Her duties at the General will include all those performed by the men, and she expects to take advantage of every opportunity in preparing herself to become a specialist in obstetrics."
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Memphis - First Facts - Women as Physicians, 1934

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The South Accepts Capable Women in the Professions"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...Hospitals, universities and laboratories, as well as research institutions are ringing with the tread of women marching shoulder to shoulder with men; meeting the same requirements in work and measuring up to the intellectual standards of men and the job..." -- "...The University of Tennessee, in its colleges of medicine, pharmacy, dentistry and nurses, has an average of 275 women in its various branches of study, which includes medicine, laboratory technician, pharmacy, dentistry, anaesthetist, and the school of nursing..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Salary for nurses increased $1 a day"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: King, Alice; medicine; nursing; women; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "New Pay Schedules Adopted at District Meeting - Mrs. Alice King of the Shelby County Health Department, was re-elected president of the Tennessee Nurses' Association, District No. 1, yesterday at the University Center. -- Salaries for nurses were set on an average of a dollar a day higher that [sic] the schedule for the past few years. Private duty nurses' salaries were set at $6 a day for 12-hour duty, $7 for 20-hour duty, and $8 for 20-hour obstetrical and contagious disease duty..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Dr. Gladys Conreur Dies; Optometrist"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: biography; Conreur, Gladys; medicine; optometry; women; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Dr. Gladys Conreur, who pioneered for her sex in the field of optometry in Memphis, died at 6 a.m. today at Methodist Hospital of complications from an appendicitis operation. She was 28. -- Dr. Conreur was the only woman optometrist in Memphis, and left her home and two children to take up the profession alongside her husband, Dr. M. C. Conreur, who has offices at Goldsmith's department store. She received her degree from Southern College of Optometry after graduating from Tech High School. She had been practicing for two years..."

Malone, executive secretary of District No. 1, Tennessee State Nurses Association, is directing a census of registered Memphis nurses available for voluntary military and civilian service as part of a national survey by the Nursing Council on National Defense, under auspices of the U.S. Public Health Service..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "No Shortage of Nurses Here"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; war; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Altho Memphis Has Sent 22 To Help Out Uncle Sam - Memphis has 'given' 22 nurses to the army and navy. -- But so far, according to Miss Mattie Malone of the Nurses' Official Registry, Memphis has not suffered a shortage of nurses. -- She points out, however, that a number of SOS calls from small hospitals and clinics outside of Memphis, but in the Memphis territory, are going unanswered. -- 'I'm sorry we haven't been able to fill those jobs, but the younger nurses want army or navy duty, and most of the nurses who have been out of school for some time have their families or own homes in Memphis and don't care to go elsewhere.' -- There always are from 400 to 420 nurses on the registry's active files..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Memphis Schools of Nursing Join Program For Enrollment of 50,000 Students This Year"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; war; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "U.T. Among Those Taking The Lead: New Classes Set -- You're finishing high school next June. -- You're 18, attractive, have personality, character and a desire to serve humanity as well as to achieve financial independence. -- Dad could advance you a few hundred dollars, but not enough for a college education. -- What's the answer to your problem? -- Probably an accredited school of nursing, where in three years you will be able to fit yourself for a job that will pay you a good deal more than the average selling or clerical job. -- You're not only welcome at such a school, but Uncle Sam is begging for you--calling for enrollment of 50,000 student nurses this year..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gilkey, Ada

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Nurses To Pay Tribute Friday To Memphis' Angels Of Mercy"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Kennedy, Imogene; medicine; nursing; war; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A service flag with 79 stars honoring Memphis nurses who already have joined the Army or Navy or are soon to do so, will be presented at a meeting of District No. 1 of the Tennessee State Nurses' Association at University Center at 7:30 o'clock Friday night by Mrs. Richard Saint, representing the local chapter of the Red Cross... Mrs. Frances Cunningham will conduct a memorial service in honor of Miss Imogene Kennedy, a graduate of the University of Tennessee's School of Nursing, who has been missing since the fall of Corregidor. Miss Clarice Corbett will place a gold star on the service flag for Miss Kennedy, and a bugler from the American Legion will sound taps...."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Girls - Here's Your Opportunity To Serve!"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; war; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "More And Still More Nurses Is The Need Of Today As Hospital Authorities Strive To Meet The Government's Urgent Call And To Fill Vacancies Created By Wartime Demands - Memphis needs 1000 student nurses! -- The city's four hospital schools are making plans to expand their facilities this Summer to take care of that number in line with the Nationwide movement to enroll 50,000 capable young women in schools of nursing..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Young Memphis Women Receive Recognition for Stellar Work With Nurses Aides"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Caption under top photo reads, "The ceremony and business session were sponsored by the Volunteer Special Services Section of the American Red Cross, Memphis Chapter. The volunteers received the citations for 'fine work during the war.'" -- Caption under the bottom photo reads, "Miss Dorothy Ballard (7), and more than 100 other young women received Nurses Aide merit certificates from Red Cross officials last night. At the speakers' table in the Officers Club were Mrs. Walter Chandler (1), Mrs. Carroll Turner (2), Mayor Chandler (3), Frank R. Ahlgren (4), editor of The Commercial Appeal, Mrs. Dave Gaut (5), and Mrs. Lena Lyon Saino (6)."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Demand For Nurses Critically Exceeds Supply; Marriage One Big Reason"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...There are many reasons why the R.N. is disappearing from the bedside of patients. Basically, it is because not enough young women are entering the profession, not enough are being graduated. -- In recent years, recruitment has increased and there are more women (430,000) in nursing today than 10 years ago. But demand continually outruns the supply. -- Where do the nurses go? Dan Cupid strikes the first blow. More than 30 per cent annually drop out of school, primarily because of marriage, or marry after graduation. They go off to raise families and their services are lost to the profession a number of years." -- Caption reads: "Common Goal - When these senior students are graduated from the Baptist Hospital School of Nursing, they will be fitted for a lifetime profession which offers rapidly growing opportunities or progress. Miss Nancy Powell (left) of Hayti, Mo., Miss Betty Lee (center) of Paragould, Ark., and Miss Sarah Sudbeck of Lexington, Miss., and their classmates are studying obstetrical nursing here."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Clemens, Ida
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Nursing Profession Short Of Facilities, Funds"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...Despite the many attractions, not enough young girls are entering the profession. Shortage of hospital nurses with an R.N. (licensed as a registered nurse) has been a chronic ailment here and throughout the country a long time. Now the problem is fast becoming acute. It is most felt at the actual bedside of the patient. -- Last month, the Nurses' Official Registry received 1,406 calls from Memphis hospitals for registered nurses. The registry was able to fill only 970. Throughout the year, and average of 308 calls went unfilled each month..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Clemens, Ida

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: clothing; education; medicine; nursing; women; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "CAP TALK - These four women illustrate different levels of the professional nurse, from freshman student to RN. All are at Methodist Hospital."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "An acute shortage of nurses has triggered a 'piracy' policy at Memphis hospitals and they raid each other to fill desperately undermanned staffs, the Mid-South Medical Center reported today..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Methodist School of Nursing Groundbreaking
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: buildings; education; medicine; Methodist Hospital School of Nursing; nursing; women; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Las Savell, director of public relations at Methodist Hospital, holds a groundbreaking shovel as nurses say a prayer before ceremonies began at the new site for the hospital's School of Nursing. Since the school was founded in 1921 it has graduated 1,290 registered nurses. The new school will accommodate 250 students and will be capable of graduating 75 nurses a year, more than twice the present potential."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "'Nurse Practitioners' Ready to Aid Doctors"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Eight registered nurses, the first students in a pilot program at the University of Tennessee Medical Units, returned to their jobs today with skills which their instructors said will enable them to ease the work load of physicians. -- Having completed four months of intensive classroom training and clinical experience, the nurses now must prove themselves, for 12 weeks before becoming the first registered nurses certified by U-T as 'adult nurse practitioners.' They will be nurses who have been trained to perform some duties usually performed by physicians, said Dr. Iris Pearce and Pat Brisley, co-directors of the program..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Pharmacy Profession Big Business For Women"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; pharmacy; women; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...Of the 120 freshman students who will begin classes Thursday, more than half will be women, said Dr. Seldom D Feurt, dean of the College of Pharmacy. -- Dr. Feurt said the percentage of women students in pharmacy has been going up dramatically for the past 10 years, with an increase of about 10 per cent each year. -- About 45 per cent of UT's total enrollment of pharmacy students at the under graduate level (320 students) are women. Of the 42 students in the doctoral program, seven are women..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "52 Filipino Nurses To Ease Shortage"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; Philippines; nursing; women; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The first of 52 Filipino nurses being brought to Memphis to help ease a critical shortage at City of Memphis Hospitals will arrive here March 22, CMH officials said today. -- Twenty-one male and female nurses will be in the first group, hospital officials reported. More will arrive April 1 and arrivals will continue until a total of 52 is reached. -- Jerry Novak, assistant administrator at CMH, said the nurses will receive language training and an intensive orientation program to supplement the schooling they received for the bachelor of nursing degrees in The Philippines. -- They must take state examinations before they can practice as registered nurses, he said. -- The nurses temporarily will be housed in the Marcus Haase Residence in the City of Memphis Hospital complex. -- CMH officials announced last fall the hospital would import nurses from The Philippines because of a shortage of almost 200 registered nurses at the hospital complex. -- Wheeler Lipes, CMH administrator, said the shortage has resulted from the hospital having to offer starting salaries of less than $700 a month to registered nurses, while other Memphis hospitals start RNs at more than $700."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Filipino Nurses Ask Transfers"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; Philippines; nursing; women; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "City of Memphis Hospital officials today said they will meet Thursday with a group of Filipino nurses who want to transfer to hospitals in other parts of the country. -- During the past year, 101 Filipino nurses have been brought to the hospital to ease a nurse shortage, the hospital paying $620 in recruiting fees for each nurse. -- The nurses are bound to CMH by one-year work visas, most of which will expire by the end of April. -- Immigration authorities here said many of the nurses are hoping to transfer to warmer climates, especially California, where there are more Filipino men. -- Wheeler L. Lipes, administrator, said he opposes the transfers because he does not want Memphis to become a 'supply source and distribution point' for Filipino nurses. Immigration officials, however, said the hospital has little hold on the nurses after the 12 month visas expire."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Graves Winner: Medical Director of City Hospital"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: City of Memphis Hospital; medicine; Pearce, Iris A.; women; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Dr. Iris A. Pearce, medical director of City of Memphis Hospital, is the 1981 winner of the L.M. Graves Memorial Health award, the Mid-South Medical Center Council/Health Systems Agency announced today. -- Dr. Pearce, 60, was unanimously picked by a selection committee as the 16th recipient of the Graves award, given annually to the professional or lay person who, in its opinion, has contributed the most signifcantly to health in the community during the current or preceding years... -- ...A 1950 graduate of the University of Tennessee Center for the Health Sciences Medical School, Dr. Pearce was the second woman intern at John Gaston Hospital, later to become CMH. She was its first woman resident in internal medicine, the first woman chief resident in internal medicine at CMH, and the first woman medical director of a Memphis hospital..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Nursing Shortage Prompts Local Conference"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; nursing; women; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Help Wanted: 400 Nurses. Benefits include flexible schedules, career opportunities and a national average salary of $20,500 per year. For further information, call any Memphis-area hospital. -- Like cities all over the country, hospital throughout Memphis are feeling the shortage of nurses and are trying to do something to solve the problem. At a meeting of the Memphis chapter of the American Association of Critical Care Nurses, which was held Thursday at the Methodist Hospital School of Nursing, nurse recruiters from some local hospitals were on hand to discuss the shortage and possible solutions. -- Janet Rail, nursing recruiter with the Regional Medical Center, told the group that out of the 400 vacancies in Memphis hospitals, nearly half of those are in the critical care area..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Orthopedic doctor breaks through stereotypes"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; orthopedics; Whittle, A. Paige; women; 1990s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Growing up in Massachusetts, playing basketball, field hockey and softball brought A. Paige Whittle her share of contact with orthopedic medical specialists. -- There was a broken finger and a broken collar bone plus an assortment of sprains and strains. For her, orthopedics became entertwined with sports. -- That connection is one reason she is now Dr. Whittle, 31, an orthopedic surgeon and The Campbell Clinic's first female faculty member. The clinic, founded in 1920, is internationally known and doubles as the orthopedic surgery department for the University of Tennessee, Memphis. -- She's one of 25 clinic members and one of three with a particular interest in orthopedic trauma. Her professional interests include research and her work days last 10 or 12 hours. Sports is relegated to jogging and playing on the clinic's softball team...."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Powers, Mary

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Mrs. Warner Dies, Health Crusader"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: biography; John Gaston Hospital; medicine; nursing; Warner, Lena Angevine; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Founder Of Nurses' School In Memphis - One of Tennessee's most colorful personalities and who had contributed much to the progress of medicine and research, died last night in Knoxville, Tenn. She was Mrs. Lena A. Warner, founder of the school of nursing at old Memphis General Hospital (now John Gaston). Mrs. Warner had a distinguished career as student, wife, Army nurse, doctor, research scientist, bacteriologist, lecturer, health crusader and organizer. She had lived in Knoxville for the past 35 years and died in a nursing home there after a long illness. She was 81. -- Graduated in Memphis -- Born in Grenada, Miss., Mrs. Warner graduated from St. Mary's Episcopal Boarding School in Memphis in 1887 and became a graduate nurse in 1889. In 1897 she organized the school of nursing here. In her long and useful career, she left her mark on preventive medicine and in public health work. -- Last April, many outstanding figures in the medical and nursing world met in Memphis to do her honor at the unveiling of a portrait painted of her by Jascha Shaffran which now hangs in Mascus Haase Nurses Home at John Gaston -- Nurse In Charge -- During her career, Mrs. Warner served as nurse in charge of Navy Yellow Fever experiments, organized many Red Cross chapters in Tennessee and served as president of Tennessee State Nurses Association for many years. -- A sister, Mrs. Warren A. Cole of Memphis died in February. Mrs. Frank Longinotti and Miss Elizabeth Cole of Memphis are nieces and there are several nieces and nephews in Grenada who survive. -- Services at 3 p.m. Saturday at Cosmopolitan Funeral home, Rev. Theodore N. Barth officiating. Burial in Elmwood."
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Memphis - Biography - Warner, Mrs. Lena A.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Dr. Riley followed her dream"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: medicine; pediatrics; Riley, Frances Osborn; women; 1990s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...She was one of three women who started with her class at UT-Memphis medical school. She was the only woman to graduate on June 11, 1951. -- And she graduated first in her class, despite barriers such as professors who asked if she'd like to be excused from urology lectures. Her class ranking secured for her a prestigious internship at Philadelphia General Hospital. After a short residency in Ann Arbor, Mich., she returned to Memphis for a residency in pediatrics at John Gaston Hospital. -- She taught at the medical school and worked in public health before going into private practice in Whitehaven..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituary for Memphis' First Woman Dentist
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brooks, May; dentistry; medicine; women; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Services Are Monday For Mrs. May Brooks - Believed To Have Been First Woman Dentist Here - Services for Mrs. May L. Brooks, believed to have been the first woman dentist to practice in Memphis, will be held at 4 Monday afternoon at National Funeral home by the Rev. Eric Greenwood. Burial will be in Forest hill. She was 75. -- Mrs. Brooks died at 1:18 yesterday afternoon at Baptist Memorial where she became a patient Wednesday. After her marriage to Dr. W.W. Brooks, a dentist, she became interested in the profession and studied at Northwestern. -- At graduation she took second honors in a class of 300 men. She returned to Memphis and began her practice in 1903. For 24 years she had offices in the Fisher Building. She retired in 1938 because of ill health and had been living at Hotel Gayoso.e was an honorary lifetime member of the Tennessee State Dental Society and of the American Dental Association. She preferred to be known by her married name instead of being addressed as 'doctor.' -- She leaves a daughter, Mrs. John H.A. Campbell of Los Angeles, who is also a dentist, and was graduated from the University of Tennessee with high honors."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "There Is Much Gratitude For the Visiting Nurses"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Junior League; medicine; nursing; Visiting Nurse Association; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In Six Months They Have Made More Than 850 Calls to the Ill -- ...He was talking about a registered nurse from the Visiting Nurse Association. In six months, more than 850 visits have been made in all parts of the city to all types of cases. Junior League is sponsor. -- ...Miss Mary Frances Ward, director of the association, says cancer, tuberculosis, diabetes and heart cases, in that order, are the most frequent occasions for visits. The association works closely with the West Tennessee Cancer Clinic. -- But the nurses handle everything from giving shots to small children exposed to measles to caring for an elderly lady with a broken hip. -- Visiting nurses thus fill an important gap in medical care, intensified by overcrowding of hospitals, burdens of extended illness and other cases requiring special attention but not hospitalization. -- ...All visits are made under direction of the family physician to persons of every economic status. Some 65 per cent pay full or part cost. But service without exceptions is available to all, regardless of ability to pay."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Call 7-3301, a Voice Will Say: 'This Is Your Visiting Nurse'"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Junior League; medicine; nursing; Visiting Nurse Association; Ward, Mary Frances; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "It's Been Years Since We've Had Any -- On Monday Memphis will have for the first time since the mid-1920's a full-scale, organized visiting nurse service for individuals and families. -- It is the product of two years of work by the Junior League. Their Follies of 1950 and the Junior League cook book provided most of the $30,000 to start the project. -- The Visiting Nurse Association starts off in a leased building--a one-time rooming house--at 1080 Madison with a director and two staff nurses." -- Photo caption at top reads: "Visiting Nurses in smart blue uniforms with work kits packed to start off from Visiting Nurse Association headquarters. Mrs. Reba Forrest (left) and Mrs. Lois Hollomon will begin a service in Memphis Monday which every other city about our size, 1100 in all, already has. Creators of VNA hope the case load will be so heavy that staff expansion will be necessary." -- Bottom caption reads: "Miss Mary Frances Ward, director of VNA, comes from Atlanta Branch of the University of Georgia where she was assciate professor of nursing education."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Nunn, William B.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jamae's Hi-Hatters Provide The Ultimate In Hot Music"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hi-Hat Club; Hi-Hatters; Jamae; jazz; music; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Artists From Other Night Spots Use Free Time To Listen And Applaud New Organization - And There Is No Greater Praise -- Hottest jazz combination to come out of Memphis since Jimmie Lunceford's day is that six-piece outfit the gifted Jamae has put together under the name the Hi-Hatters down at the new Hi-Hat Club on Highway 61 south of Memphis. This sextet and its maestra are the musical talk of the town at the moment. -- Any Monday night, when the musicians at most of the other outlying spots are taking a rest, you can discover them assembled at the Hi-Hat for the privilege of listening to Jamae's inspired work at the piano and vibraphone, plus the support of her five fine sidemen. When one music-maker takes a free evening to listen to another, that's the ultimate tipoff as to the quality, and these Monday evening sessions just below that muchly-controverted bridge are nothing less than a tribute by fellow artists to a little lady who has no peers in the field hereabouts. -- When she was featured with the orchestra of her husband, Owen Elkins, Jamae always yearned for a chance to experiment with what hepcats call 'a small combo' of her own. Opening at the Hi-Hat gave her that opportunity. She got together Trumpeter Bix Corley, on of the village's better Gabriels; Clarinetist Joe Bracciante, member of a family steeped in the Memphis musical tradition for three generations; Guitarist Jerome Gilbert, Drummer Guyton Nunnally and Bassist Victor Danreuther. Sharing their mistress' enthusiasm, the boys plunged into rehearsal with a determination to come up with something fresh and distinctive. The results speak for themselves. Jamae and her Hi-Hatters are the treat of the Summer. -- The Hi-Hat also serves an excellent meal and stages a twice-nightly floor show, the highlight of which is Lynn Curtis' tap dancing with baton. The place is open every night in the week except Tuesday, from 5 in the afternoon until the wee sma' hours of the morn. -- Incidentally, Jamae has laughingly requested us to deny the rumors that her separation from the rotund Owen Elkins is something more than a mere professional parting. They are still quite happily married."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Martin, Harry

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Recap of Benny Goodman concert
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Goodman, Benny; jazz; Memphis Symphony Orchestra; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "25 YEARS AGO - June 17, 1946 -- Clarinetist Benny Goodman intoxicated Memphis last night with 'Sunny Side of the Street,' 'Lady Be Good,' 'Sweet Georgia Brown,' 'Waitin' for the Sunrise,' 'Body and Soul' and 'Tiger Rag.' The talented Mr. Goodman appeared as the guest artist with the Memphis Symphony Orchestra in open air concert at Overton Park shell. A capacity audience of fans rent the soft velvet of the night with shrills and shrieks as the 'king of swing' gave them the jiviest of jumpin' jam sessions. Goodman, who is equally skilled and knowledgeable in the field of classical music, gave the long hairs some thrills too, playing a number of difficult concert pieces. The popular young Vincent de Frank conducted."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Death of Jimmy Lunceford Recalls His First Band Here"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Lunceford, Jimmie; music; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The world famous jazz orchestra of Jimmy Lunceford, top flight negro musician who died Saturday night in Seaside, Ore., was formed here by him in 1925 when he was teaching at Manassas High School. -- The body of the 47-year-old maestro will be buried here in the family plot at Elmwood after services in New York City. Arrangements are incomplete. -- Born in Mississippi-Lunceford, who was born James Melvin Lunceford in Fulton, Miss., collapsed in a music store late Saturday after complaining of severe headaches during the day. Coroner William Thompson said the death was due to natural causes. -- True to tradition, his band played its scheduled engagement an hour later. It was a one-night stand on a West Coast tour. Manager Eddie Rosenberg said the musicians would disband permanently after a memorial program at Rockaway Beach, Ore., Wednesday night. -- Still with the band was the piano player who was graduated in music along with Lunceford at Fisk University. They came here together in 1925 when Lunceford went to Manassas as music teacher and football coach, Ethel Tarpley of 1941 Felix, Lunceford's sister-in-law, recalled last night. -- She did not recall the pianist's name, but he served as the nucleus around which Lunceford, using Manassas students, built an organization destined to become internationally known. In 1937 the band toured 30 countries in Europe. -- Married Fisk Classmate -- After four years at Manassas, Lunceford gave up teaching to take his orchestra on the road. He returned to Memphis at intervals, and in 1934 he married Rose Chrystal Tulli, a teacher at Booker T. Washington High School, whom he had met at Fisk. They maintained a home in White Plains, N.Y. -- Lunceford, who started as a guitarist and later mastered the saxophone, clarinet, trombone and flute, was a licensed pilot. He flew his personal plane wherever he went, taking four of his musicians along in the five-place twin-engine Cessna. -- He was last here May 25 when he flew in from Nashville after playing for his fraternity, Kappa Alpha Psi."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jimmy Lunceford
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Lunceford, Jimmie; music; portraits; 1990s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jimmy Lunceford developed a popular jazz style. From Memphis, the Jimmy Lunceford Orchestra toured the world, gaining a reputation for its sound and showmanship."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Ex-agent recalls local Basie gig"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Basie, William "Count"; Brescia, Matty; jazz; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jazz pianist William 'Count' Basie enjoyed popularity in Memphis for more than three decades, but times have changed considerably for black entertainers since the musician played his first gig on Beale Street. -- Matty Brescia, a retired agent who said he booked a number of black entertainers in town years ago, said Basie, who died Thursday in Hollywood, Fla., at age 79, signed a contract to appear at the old Beale Street Auditorium in December 1951. -- 'When I booked Count Basie, you couldn't book a Negro entertainer into a white auditorium,' Brescia said. 'Then they wouldn't let white people in. My wife, who worked the box office, and I were the only white people there and there were about 1,000. The place was packed. But he told me he was proud to play Beale Street for his people.' -- Brescia said admission for the dance was $1.50. Basie agreed to play for $500, with $100 down. -- The musician, known for his upbeat swing style and compositions such as 'One O'Clock Jump,' 'Jumpin' at the Woodside' and 'Don't You Miss Your Baby?' last played town at The Peabody on Oct. 28. -- But the prices have gone up. The tickets were priced at $20 and $25, and neither show at the Skyway was filled to capacity."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Memphis Negro Pianist 'Sends' the Jazz Critics"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; music; Newborn, Phineas, Jr.; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "His Playing Is Called 'Exciting' - Many Refer to Him as 'Genius' -- Memphis, which gave to the jazz world such immortals as Handy, Lunceford and Bessie Smith, has another negro artist who has the jazz critics polishing up their best adjectives to describe his piano technique. -- Phineas Newborn Jr. is about to become famous nationally before Memphis is even aware of him. -- A month ago Fred Cook of WREC asked me, 'Is this Phineas Newborn who was on the Steve Allen show the same Phineas Newborn who used to play at the Plantation Inn over in West Memphis? He's real great.' I couldn't answer Fred's question then, but the answer is yes. -- Phineas has out a new album for Atlantic called 'Here Is Phineas.' Cook has been featuring two or three numbers from it each afternoon on his WREC radio program..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Johnson, Robert

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Charles Lloyd is From Memphis"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Lloyd, Charles; music; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Charles Lloyd, rapidly becoming one of the top names in jazz music, is a graduate of Manassas, got his bachelor's and master's in music at University of Southern California. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Parker, 2082 Claremont Circle. His real father was the late Dr. C. Lloyd Sr., but Parker has considered him like a son, and Charles came home last month from the Riviera just to see his step-father when he became ill. His sister, Johnice Parker, goes to Melrose. Lloyd was the first jazz artist ever invited to play at Norway's Bergen Festival, on June 7. In the past, it has been strictly a classical festival. he got a big following on the West Coast, particularly in San Francisco, then became famous overnight when European critics hailed him as a new sensation. Comedian Bill Cosby has hired him to write the music for Cosby's tv special this fall. Lloyd is 28."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "1,500 Were One O'Clock Jumping"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Basie, William "Count"; jazz; music; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "When stocky Bill (Count) Basie sits down behind his piano, he seems to grow a foot. If his reception at the Club Paradise is any indication, he has a Memphis following to match his musical stature. -- An estimated 1,500 fans gathered last night to hear 'the Count' and his 17-piece band. Few went away disappointed. -- Author of a seemingly endless list of all-time favorites including the immortal 'One O'Clock Jump,' Basie demonstrated his inimitable keyboard artistry until well into the morning hours. -- AN INTERVIEW -- What about rock and roll - would he play it? -- 'You're damned right I would, in a minute, if I had the feeling for it,' said Basie in an interview. 'But the kids around my house say they've got 'Big Daddy' - they've tried to teach me the beat of the stuff but I just don't seem to catch it.' -- STUDIO MONEY -- Basie said that, other than the 'gimmick stuff for the teen-agers,' the big money for musicians today is to be found 'around the studios,' playing for movies television and recording. -- 'It's pretty hard these days to find and keep top-notch side men,' he said. 'Usually the studios snatch up the really great side men - that's where the money is and you can't blame a man for not staying around home.' -- 'Big Daddy' recalled one of his trips to the Bluff City when the big bands were swinging in Memphis. -- PLAYED AT HANDY -- 'I can remember when I met one of the greatest entertainers in show business, Sammy Davis Jr.,' he said. 'I was playing at the Handy Theater on the same bill with the Will Maston Trio. Davis was a part of the Maston Trio and I was highly impressed by him. -- 'I thought people should see this kid. So I took him with me to the Strand Theater (in New York) and after that he never really looked back. He really wrecked that theater.'"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz from Memphis"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Lloyd, Charles; music; Soviet Union; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Only a few years ago, jazz music was strictly forbidden in the Soviet Union. 'Nyet,' the big wheels in the Kremlin said, 'such music is the product of decadent capitalism and it's bad for the masses.' Or something like that. -- Then we arranged a cultural exchange with the Russians. The famed Bolshoi ballet company performed in New York and Benny Goodman and his band - among other entertaining groups - toured Russian cities. New Yorkers applauded the Bolshoi dancers and Soviet audiences gave standing ovations to Goodman..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Cool Sounds, All That Jazz Booked For Aug. 4 Festival"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Memphis Jazz Festival; music; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Memphis will become the jazz capital of the country Aug. 4 when the first Memphis Jazz Festival is held at the Mid-South Coliseum. -- Sponsors of the regional festival--direct outgrowth of the world-famous long-standing Newport Jazz Festival--yesterday said the 'magnificent facilities' of the coliseum were a great factor in bringing six top-ranking jazz figures here. They are: Jimmy Smith Trio, Dizzy Gillespie's All Stars, Ramsey Lewis Trio, Nina Simone, the Herbie Mann Octet and Cannonball Adderly's Quintet. All will come here after performing at Newport and other cities in the developing jazz concert concept. -- George Wein, who sponsored the first Newport Jazz Festival in 1954, and all since, was in Memphis yesterday to promote the Memphis Jazz Festival, latest in a spread of the regional festival concept he started in 1960..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Knott, John

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Film Notes Memphian's Jazz Art"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: film; jazz; Lloyd, Charles; music; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A first in film biography is being created in Memphis. -- It is the story of Memphis jazz musician Charles Lloyd, being filmed by Eric Sherman of Los Angeles, a Yale student. -- It all began when Mr. Sherman, a student of sociology with an interest in jazz, heard a concert by Mr. Lloyd at Town Hall in New York. At the concert, Mr. Sherman decided that 'everything I wanted to express about jazz could be expressed in a study of the life of Charles as a man and an artist.' -- He received a year's leave of absence from Yale to make the film and began shooting in May. 'It will be the first such film ever made,' he said yesterday. 'My father, Vincent Sherman, is a film director and I guess I've got it in my blood.' -- Mr. Lloyd, who is 29, is a 1956 graduate of Manassas High, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Parker of 1082 Clarmont Circle. He received his bachelor's and master's degrees in music from the University of Southern California. He plays the tenor saxophone and flute. -- The film will be an hour long, Mr. Sherman said, and added that he has definite commitments from an educational television network to show it..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cortese, James
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Memphis Joins Jazz Circuit"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Adderley, Cannonball; Gaskin, Vic; jazz; Mann, Herbie; music; Simone, Nina; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "It Was a 'Happening,' Baby--Real Cool" -- "'A happening' happened in Memphis last night - and according to its producer it will recur next year, much to the delight of Mid-South jazz fans. -- 'The happening' was the first of what promises to become the annual Memphis Jazz Festival. In 1968 the Memphis bash, say those involved, will join the ranks of the St. Louis and Ohio Valley jazz festivals. -- The first Memphis Jazz Festival had 6,000 fans by the ear for over four hours at the Mid-South Coliseum. -- They were all there - a handful of hippies, Flower Children, numerous miniskirted lasses; and what counts most, the many people who simply 'dig' the sounds. -- They came for one purpose - to hear the giants, the Cannonball Adderley Quintet; Herbie Mann and Octet; songstress Nina Simone; Ramsey Louis and hist Trio; the man with the canted horn, Dizzie Gillespie and his quintet; and the incomparable organist, Jimmy Smith, and his trio..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Performance By Ellington Fills 'Happiness' With Joy"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ellington, Duke; jazz; Le Bonheur; music; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In a half-century as a performing artist, Duke Ellington may never have played on a worse piano. He may never have had a smaller nor younger audience - so young that they probably did not know who Duke Ellington was. -- But his little concert last night for a half-dozen patients of Le Bonheur Children's Hospital had a warmth that went beyond the overheated room in the basement of the hospital with the name that means, with what must often be a cruel irony, 'happiness.' -- 'If you have a perfect piano, you have no alibi,' said Mr. Ellington, at 69, going on 70, one of the elder statesmen of American music. With grace and ease and some care he sat on the bench before an old upright, while one of the women who had arranged his hospital visit said in a polite gasp, 'Oh, I knew the piano was not in good shape but I didn't know the top was off the seat.'"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jennings, Robert

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Blues, Born Black, Are Put Back On Track"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: blues; jazz; Johnson, Leon; music; Thieme, Darius; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...Voice inflections weren't perfect, for the African tribal song was born 5,000 miles away. -- But Central High School band director James Harris, a Negro, seemed to feel the cowbell he was tapping and Mrs. Henrietta Boggs, Carver Junior High music teacher, made the piano suffice for bongos. -- Dr. Darius L. Thieme blew upon his bamboo flute and Leon Johnson shook his maracas. Both men make black music their study in a federally funded program at Fisk University in Nashville. -- And yesterday in Central's auditorium, the city school teachers of music sang 'E je ko-mode ko wa o' and learned about the concept of 'black music in culture.' -- They were also scolded by Dr. Thieme, project director of Fisk's black studies in music, for being the caboose on the end of a long train. -- In the past few years, charges have been made not only that textbooks lie about the Negro's roles in history but also that credit for inspiring the blues, acid rock and cool jazz has been denied Negroes. -- Music teachers, the session concluded, could take the lead in giving credit where credit is due..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Two Black Jazz Specialists Return To Hometown Stand"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; music; Newborn, Phineas, Jr.; Sharecropper, the; Stone, Lee; Viking Lounge; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Two black artists who played in the band at Melrose High School back in the 50s and who graduated to much finer things will be playing at separate places in their hometown tomorrow night. -- Phineas Newborn Jr., famed as a cool jazz pianist nearly a score of years, will be at the Sharecropper for a two-night stand and Lee Stone, a singer, will open at the Viking Lounge in the downtown Viking Hotel, fromerly the Wm. Len."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "A Memphis 'Guest'"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Armstrong, Louis; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "'SATCHMO' RECALLS: Louis Armstrong, the giant of jazz who died in July at age 71, was smoking marijuana as far back as 40 years ago and maintained a lifelong respect for the drug as a 'sort of medicine' even though he later quit using it, a new biography says. 'We always looked at pot--marijuana--as a sort of medicine, a cheap drunk and with much better though than one that's full of liquor,' said Armstrong in letters to British music writer Max Jones and trumpeter John Chilton, old friends and authors of 'Louis.' 'Satchmo' spent nine days in a California jail before marijuana possession charges were dropped against him in 1931. he was arrested the following year in Memphis but he says he smoked the incriminating cigaret in his cell and 'demolished the evidence.'"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Gather At Sharecropper Today, Ye Dixieland Lovers"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Baker, Bob; Fine, Johnny; Franklin, Abe; Haley, Sonny; jazz; Koopman, Rene; music; Orth, Emil; River City Six; Sharecropper, the; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A new Dixieland group - with 220 years of musical experience - makes its professional bow at the Sharecropper from 6 to 9 today. -- The River City Six is led by Emil Orth, former trombonist for Bob Scobey's great Dixieland bunch. He has made previous Sunday appearances at the Sharecropper, but he wanted to play some true, commercial Dixieland."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Session Stars Tenor Sax Virtuoso"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Club Paradise; Coleman, George; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A new series of Jazz on Sunday Afternoon will get underway at Club Paradise at 6 p.m. today, with onetime Memphian George Coleman, the tenor sax virtuoso, as featured star. -- Ed Horne, who is putting together the series, said, 'I only hope we can make this young lad feel at home again with a full house. I think it's quite honorable to have a Memphian to start the sessions and George is among the top in today's tenor jazz men.' -- Coleman attended Chicago Conservatory of Music after his Manassas High days in Memphis and began his big-time career with drummer, Max Roach, followed by affiliations with Slide Hampton's band, the Clark Terry big band, Miles Davis and Elvin Jones' quintet..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Artist Returns To Paradise"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Club Paradise; jazz; music; Strozier, Frank; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Memphian who went elsewhere to make a name in the jazz world is returning home today for a session at Club Paradise. -- Frank Strozier, a master on both the alto horn and the flute, is the guest artist at the 6 p.m. 'Jazz on Sunday' at the club on Georgia. -- Though he came out of Manassas High, Strozier trained at the Chicago Conservatory of Music and California Tech before hitting it big accompanying the late trumpet star Lee Morgan. -- In the interim, his travels from Memphis have led him to some of the greatest groups in jazz today--Oliver Nelson's Band, Quincy Jones' Orchestra, and the Shelley Manne Quintet, among them. -- Jazz master Ed Horne says Strozier is only the second Memphian to appear in Club Paradise's series of jazz programs which will continue on Sunday's through the summer."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Homecoming by Marvin Stamm Is a Thrill to Jazz Lovers"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; music; Stamm, Marvin; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Marvin Stamm, an aspiring young musician at Central High School not too many years ago, returned to Memphis last night and showed an audience of about 1,800 people at the Overton Park Shell why he is one of the country's top jazz trumpeters. -- Performing with the Tommy Ferguson Trio, the Memphis State Jazz Band and the Jazz Symphony Orchestra, Stamm was the guest artist in this season's final 'Music Under the Stars' concert. -- Stamm, alternating on trumpet and flugel horn, exhibited a brilliant sensitivity in his expressive and seemingly effortless performance...."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Gillespie Stuns MSU Audience With Virtuosity"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gillespie, Dizzy; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Dizzy Gillespie is described by many musicians as 'the greatest trumpet player in the world.' He also is a splendid comedian, a fine blues singer and a master of the conga drum. -- By himself, he is a rare artist who commands the respect of the musical world and mesmerizes audiences around the world. -- Throw in the other three members of the Gillespie Quartet and you have a concert that reaches to the depth of the soul and makes it difficult - if not impossible - for the star's admirers to remain still during a performance. -- Last night's concert at Memphis State's University Center ballroom, highlighting MSU's Jazz Week, was an excellent example of what Dizzy Gillespie is all about...."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lamb, Phillip B.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Duke Will Renew Old Ties Tonight"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ellington, Duke; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Duke Ellington will be back in town tonight, adding another page to an association with Memphis which dates back more than three decades and is highly varied. -- The 74-year-old patriarch of popular music will herd his orchestra into the ballroom of Memphis State's University Center for a concert at 8 tonight. Tickets will be available at the door. The advance sale has been modest. -- Ellington's two most recent Memphis performances have been in a guest star capacity - along with his orchestra - in Memphis Symphony Orchestra pops concerts Jan. 30, 1969, and Sept. 24, 1970. -- But his Memphis visits far predate those times. One, for example, found Ellington and orchestra playing in downtown Memphis' Orpheum in December, 1937, and thereby reviving a precedent if not setting one..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "At 67, The King Of Clarinet Is Still Swinging"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Goodman, Benny; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “With a clarinet at his side, the musical score on his lap and his fans peeping through the dressing room door, Benny Goodman prepares for his concert – one of ‘thousands and thousands’ he has given during his life. -- But the ‘King of Swing,’ famed for his bands and his jazz and the sounds that have come from his clarinet for the past 40 years, said that each audience is a new challenge. -- ’I’m still breaking my leg,’ each time on stage, he said. ‘It’s still show business.’ -- And since Goodman is a living legend of sorts, known to music lovers as the subject of 1955’s ‘The Benny Goodman Story,’ he also has to put up with the little interferences that come with being a star. -- As he enters the concert hall, he is stopped for his autograph. As he studies and sings the music for the performance, admirers poke their heads into his dressing room. Before he has a chance to warm up his clarinet, his lips and his stomach, he finds himself in another interview – also one of thousands and thousands he has given during his life….”
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Barrett, Katherine

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Pops to Feature Ella Fitzgerald"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fitzgerald, Ella; jazz; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Ella Fitzgerald, famed jazz singer who performed as a teen-ager at the old Church Park Auditorium on Beale Street, will be guest star at the pops concert of Memphis Symphony Orchestra next Feb. 24 in Dixon-Myers Hall at the Auditorium. -- Miss Fitzgerald, a headliner for most of her 58 years, will sing with the orchestra under direction of Vincent de Frank. -- The singer’s career began when she won a $10 prize in an amateur show at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Her appearance is made possible through a grant from the Memphis Arts Council jazz artists in residence program, according to Walter Hehmeyer, general manager of the Orchestral Society.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Festival Lists Stellar Lineup"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cole, Natalie; Gladys Knight and the Pips; Green, Al; jazz; Kool Jazz Festival; Mighty Clouds of Joy; music; Roy Ayers Ubiquity; Sylvers, the; Temptations, the; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Al Green, Natalie Cole, the Sylvers, the Mighty Clouds of Joy, Gladys Knight and the Pips, the Temptations and Roy Ayers Ubiquity were announced yesterday as the lineup for the Kool Jazz Festival July 8-9 in the Mid-South Coliseum. -- The announcement was made at a press conference by Dino Santangelo of Festival Productions, Inc., the company set up by internationally known promoter George Wein, whose many other festivals include the Newport Jazz Festival. The Memphis event is one of 13 Kool Jazz Festivals being put on this year, up from the nine shows that attracted 650,000 people last year, Santangelo said. -- Green, Ms. Cole, the Sylvers and the Mighty Clouds of Joy will hold the stage for the first night of the event, with Ms. Knight and the Pips, the Temptations and Roy Ayers Ubiquity closing it out the next evening. -- The two concerts mark the first time Wein has brought a festival event into Memphis since 1969. Santangelo said Wein decided to bring the Kool festival to Memphis this year because the records showed that about 5,000 Memphians attended last year’s Atlanta festival, ‘which made us think that there was a bigger market in Memphis for what we’re doing than we had thought.’ -- Also, he hinted that a 1978 festival is in the works for Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium. ‘Next year we may surprise you by going to larger facilities here in Memphis, because, as you know, most of our festivals are held in stadiums.’ -- The Kool Jazz Festivals are subsidized by manufacturers of Kool cigarets in return for the use of the product’s name, and the cigarette company and Festival Productions also make cash grants to community organizations in each city in which the festival plays. -- Tickets to the Memphis concerts are available by mail order from the coliseum. Over-the-counter sales will begin June 1. A free brochure describing festival details is available by writing Memphis Kool Jazz Festival, P.O. Box 911, Memphis 38101.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Perry Allen Jr., Jazz Authority, Dies At Age 52"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Allen, Perry, Jr.; jazz; music; radio; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Perry Allen Jr. of 1882 Netherwood, a longtime Memphis disk jockey and educator, died early yesterday morning at his home. He was 52. -- Mr. Allen began his broadcasting career in Memphis more than 20 years ago with the old radio station WCBR, now WLOK. Over the years he worked for several stations here including WWEE and WKNO-FM, along with several stints at WLOK. -- He was considered by many as the Mid-South’s foremost expert on jazz and was credited with introducing the first regular all-jazz program on Memphis radio….”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Newborn Symbolizes Real Memphis Music"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; music; Newborn, Phineas, Jr.; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “He is a quiet man. -- We are sitting in a shadowed room, cut off from the street noises, the afternoon’s light barely creeping through a doorway window. -- An upright piano, framed with pictures and musical scores, waits patiently across the room. -- ’I’ve been playing that piano for almost 45 years,’ he says softly and points. That’s as many years as he’s been on Earth; he grew up on it, was weaned from it and still comes back to it. -- His mother, Mrs. Rose Newborn, sits on the piano bench, leaning. ‘These youngsters,’ says the one who ought to know, ‘They don’t even know about him. This is why a lot of them don’t know him, because he’s been out of town for so many years.’ -- But enough of them knew Phineas Newborn Jr. to show up at the Ritz last Sunday night to hear a son of Memphis play. Enough to call him back to the Ritz for shows at 9 and 11 p.m. tomorrow. It will be a replay, with Fred Ford on saxophone, Earl Thomas on bass and Jeff Grayer on drums. Newborn will also be featured on tomorrow’s weekly jazz program on WLYX (FM 89.3). The show airs from 12:30 to 5 p.m. -- Ford, who sometimes is a manager for Newborn, says his friend is called the ‘Spirit of Piano’ in Japan. -- People also call his ‘Fine-us,’ but Ford says it ‘Phin-ee-us’ and when his mother mentions ‘Junior’ they know who she means. -- Newborn says, ‘Yeah, Fine-us. My daddy started that. People who see it written out say Phin-ee-us, but he started calling me Fine-us.’…”
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Conley, Michael A.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Downtown jazzed up by festival"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Memphis Traditional Jazz Festival; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...About 550 people spent a lazy afternoon yesterday walking to the various stages and enjoying some fine jazz music from both out-of-town and local musicians. -- A busboy could be seen in the service area at No. 1 Beale Street dancing up a storm to the Buck Creek Band's version of a Bessie Smith song, 'Jazzbo Brown From Memphis Town.' A waitress at the same restaurant finally just gave in and danced as she brought food and drinks to her customers. -- Many of the crowd probably were pleasantly surprised that the music played at the festival wasn't strictly Dixieland. -- George 'Doc' Ryan, festival chairman, originator of the event and a cornet player in his Memphis band, The Hot Cotton Jazz Band, defined 'traditional jazz': 'It's the jazz that was developed in America between 1900 and 1939. It includes ragtime, the blues and Dixieland in several versions: Chicago, New Orleans and West Coast and some early swing of the 1930s. Dixieland is just one part of that.'..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Donahue, Michael

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Effort begun to organize jazz foundation"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ford, Ophelia; Horne, Ed; jazz; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A Memphis disk jockey is leading an effort to create a jazz foundation to promote 'mainstream, contemporary jazz' in the city and provide a showcase for local musicians. -- Ed Horne, who has a late night jazz show on radio station WLOK, said the organizers eventually want to sponsor a major jazz festival in Memphis similar to those held in Newport, R.I., Chicago, New Orleans, San Francisco and other American cities. -- An organizational gathering for the foundation will be held at 6 p.m. Sunday at The Coach House at 1262 Union. Local jazz artists will perform, and Horne said he plans to auction 50 new albums to raise money for the foundation..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Ed Horne, jazz promoter, dies"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Horne, Ed; jazz; music; 1990s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Edward Armour Horne, a former disc jockey for radio station WLOK and a jazz promoter who brought famous artists to Memphis in the 1970s and 1980s, died Tuesday. He was 69. R.S. Lewis & Sons Funeral Home has charge. -- Horne was a disc jockey at the station in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Later he turned to promoting jazz, bringing in such greats as Pepper Adams and Quincy Jones. 'The jazz community will miss Ed greatly,' said Vasco Smith, county commissioner and jazz buff. -- Horne was a retired Postal Service supervisor. -- He leaves a daughter, Jaye S. Horne; his mother, Joy Horne; two sisters, Nanilee Banks and Jeanetta Powell, and a brother, Leonard Horne, all of Memphis."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Memphis-bred band strolls in jazz world's high cotton"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hot Cotton Jazz Band; jazz; music; Wilson, Ruby; 1990s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "If you live in the cradle of the blues, you might easily have missed out on the rebirth of one of Memphis' favorite sons. -- That's because it is happening on the West Coast, where Dixieland and blues-tinged jazz from the W.C. Handy era have become yet another California phenomenon. -- And Memphis's own Hot Cotton Jazz Band is in the thick of it. -- More than 100,000 paying customers came last spring to listen to Hot Cotton and other so-called 'traditional jazz bands' at the annual Sacramento Dixieland Jubilee. It's the oldest of dozens of festivals that have sprung up in California and, recently, found their way as close to Memphis as Chattanooga..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Belated admirers salute musician"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Lunceford, Jimmie; music; 2000s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Swing era arranger taught at Manassas High in 1920s" -- "Over the grave at Historic Elmwood Cemetery, a trumpet beckoned Memphis to remember a local music master on Saturday. -- Trumpeter Ron Herd II and nine other people gathered around the grave of bandleader and arranger Jimmie Lunceford, a former teacher at Manassas High School who became an internationally noted and respected musician of the swing era. -- On the marker, Herd laid a yellow wreath with blue flowers and a ribbon that read: 'Thanks, Mr. Lunceford.' -- The 'thank you' is part of the Jimmie Lunceford Jamboree Festival, which continues with a tribute special from 4 to 6 this evening on Blog Talk Radio (blogtalkradio.com/weallbe), an online social radio network. -- Some jazz experts rate Lunceford's musicianship up there with Duke Ellington and Count Basie. Some also consider his memory to be among the most neglected..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Group Seeks to Revive Memphis Jazz"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Easley, William; jazz; MMUSIC; music; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jazz is alive in Memphis, and MMUSIC is working to make it better. -- Some of the city's premier musicians city 'strutted their stuff' at the Overton Park Shell last night in behalf of Memphis Musicians United Supporting Improvisational Creativity, a newly organized group formed to publicize jazz in Memphis."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "A Review - Lena Horne Is Superstar At Young 62"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: concerts; Horne, Lena; jazz; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "All that can be said about Lena Horne is what has been said so many times before-- she's an incredibly beautiful lady and an inimitable performer. -- Watching her show at the Orpheum last night made it hard to believe that she's 62-years old. -- Dressed in a flowing pinkish-orange caftan gown, Miss Horne walked onto the stage like a lady. But before her 1.5 hour performance ended, she had sung some sexy, sultry numbers - classics like 'Stormy Weather' and 'The Lady Is A Tramp,' songs from her movies, shaked her rump to the funk, 'rocked' to the floor and cut loose on her rendition of a song performed by Michael Jackson in the movie, 'The Wiz' - 'You Can't Win, You Can't Break Even and You Can't Get Out of the Game.' -- The 2,000 or so in the audience loved it and Miss Horne received several standing ovations. About halfway through the show, the indefatigable Miss Horne tied a white kerchief around her neck, 'to get rid of some of the sweating. I don't mind sweating, but it takes the color out of the costume,' she told the crowd, who responded with laughter and more applause. -- 'One of the great privileges of being a lady,' she told the crowd, 'is that a lady can be just as trashy as she wants when she wants. And I'm beginning to enjoy trash more and more each year. I'm what you call a late bloomer and I'm sorry I waited so long.'..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Coffee, Gertha

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Frank Strozier performs tonight"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; MMUSIC; music; Strozier, Frank; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Saxophonist-flutist Frank Strozier, whose credits include playing with Miles Davis, Woody Shaw and Shelley Manne, returns to Memphis tonight for a rare appearance in his hometown. He will play Schreier Auditorium of the University of Tennessee Student/Alumni Center at 800 Madison at 7 p.m. -- The show is the first in a series of 'Homecoming Concerts' planned by M.M.U.S.I.C. (Memphis Musicians United Supporting Improvisational Creativity), a nonprofit group dedicated to fostering jazz. -- Strozier was born in Memphis in 1937 and began studying piano at the age of 11, switching to alto sax two years later. In 1954, he moved north and continued his studies at the Conservatory in Chicago. While there he became a member of the MJT+3 group, and when that band broke up in '59, Strozier moved on to New York. -- After a couple of years with Roy Haynes and stints with other jazzmen, he signed on for a '63 tour with Miles Davis, and in '65 moved to California at the insistence of drummer Shelley Manne. Strozier remained out west for six years and was a regular in the drummer's club, Shelley's Manne Hole, as well as getting into studio work and television shows. -- In '71 he returned to New York and took a day job in the school system (he taught science). Meanwhile, he continued sitting in with other musicians and doing his own one-nighters. -- Also in '71, Strozier was picked by down beat magazine's poll of critics as the talent deserving wider recognition. -- Throughout his career, Strozier has recorded with Manne, Hayes, Don Ellis, Woody Shaw, Chet Baker, McCoy Tyner and a number of other jazz artists, and he also has done a number of albums on his own, including Remember Me in '76 and What's Goin On in '77. -- Strozier's standing in the jazz community is evidenced by the six-hour tribute that a New York radio station paid to him and his music last May."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Fans Glad He Chose Career as Jazzman"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Mobley, Bill; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Bill Mobley had the chance to be a biologist, a researcher or a dentist. And with his education, he could have done any number of other things in the science or health care fields. -- His love of music kept him from entering either of these lucrative fields. -- Although Mobley, 28, spent almost 10 years at several universities, music was always in the back of his mind. -- Except for some occasional practice, Mobley said, he virtually put away his trumpet for the 10 years he attended Southwestern at Memphis, the University of California at Los Angeles and the University of Tennessee Center for Health Sciences. -- It was during his second year in dental school in Memphis, however, that Mobley decided to make music his career. -- 'I just felt that I had to be a musician,' he said. 'And when you become one you have to be ready to give up a certain amount of security.' -- Fortunately for jazz fans, Mobley chose to give up financial security and take his chances in music. -- During the past several years, he has met with some success. -- He has maintained a jazz quintet which performs frequently in clubs around Memphis, including a seven month stint last year at the Varsity Inn before jazz was phased out there..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Nave, Mark

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "With fame in hand, jazzmen come home"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Coleman, George; jazz; Mabern, Harold; music; Strozier, Frank; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "When George Coleman, Harold Mabern and Frank Strozier bring home their internationally known jazz music this weekend, they also will bring memories of why they had to leave Memphis to seek fame and fortune. -- The Manassas High School graduates are headliners at the Beale Street Music Festival, being held in the downtown area that was all too familiar to them and other serious musicians during their growing-up years in the 1950s. -- The three, who will play as a trio Saturday and Sunday afternoon, all now live in New York City. They left Memphis for Chicago after high school. -- Coleman, alto and tenor saxophonist, talked plainly about his reasons for leaving: -- 'The jazz opportunities in Memphis are limited. During the time when we first began to play as kids in high school, there were not a lot of jazz outlets. The Hotel Mitchell, 'Sunbeam' Mitchell's club, was known by a lot of people and musicians as a good place to sit in and have a jam session. -- 'It was a learning process for all of us during that time,' he said. 'There is no more of that.' -- Coleman said the late 1940s and 1950s produced a lot of good Memphis talent. 'It seems like after we left, the trend sort of shifted to rock and to rhythm and blues. -- 'New York is the Mecca,' Coleman said in a telephone interview from his home in Manhattan. 'Everything is here. All the jazz clubs are here. It has more jazz clubs than any place in the world. Any of the innovative processes involving jazz always begin here. -- 'Anybody who wants to get ahead and get established always has to come to New York.' -- Pianist Mabern said perfection of the craft is a prerequisite to fame. Memphis did not offer that opportunity, he said. -- 'The reason why most of the guys left Memphis is because as great as it is, learning about rhythm and blues and the environment, we had to move on to further our careers.' -- This weekend will mark one of the many times the trio has played together. They played several times with the jazz group MJT+3 in Chicago. They now play together occasionally in New York with Coleman's quartet. They all have played and recorded with some of the biggest names in the jazz world, including Wes Montgomery, Miles Davis and Max Roach. -- Mabern's plans to study at the Chicago Conservatory, where Strozier and Coleman studied, were cut short because he had no money. -- 'In Memphis we had quality, but not quantity. In Chicago, they had 10 great piano players on every corner,' Mabern said."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peace, Shelia

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Slim at his birthday celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: blues; Chatman, Peter; jazz; Memphis Slim; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Birthday Time Again - Internationally famous Memphis Slim will return from Paris, France, to celebrate his birthday in his hometown. The legendary jazz and blues pianist will perform at 8 p.m. Wednesday in the Peabody Skyway for 'A Wine and Cheese Birthday Celebration for Memphis Slim,' being planned by Harry Godwin. Slim, who will be 67, is shown above with his wife at one of his Memphis birthday parties. Reservations may be made by calling 529-4137."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Musicians Sing The Blues"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broyles, David; jazz; Johnson, Charlton; Kelley, Mike; Lonardo, Tom; MMUSIC; Mobley, Bill; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jazz. -- The four-letter word for musical improvisation conjures up images of finger-snapping beatniks, long-haired guitarists, Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman, Al Jarreau, Al Hirt. -- To local club owners, the word conjures up something else: no profit. -- David Broyles, president of the restaurant division of Overton Square Inc., selects acts for the Bombay Bicycle Club. -- At Bombay, he said, 'As many as six or seven nights a week we tried to have live jazz. It almost put us out of business. -- '(Jazz) doesn't draw enough people to support it. It's not that jazz supporters eat or drink less than anybody else,' he said. 'There are not enough of them out there who appreciate the music, who would make a special effort to see it.' -- Put another way, jazz and Memphis don't mix well..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peace, Shelia

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Hirt may horn in on new home"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; Hirt, Al; jazz; Morris, William "Bill"; music; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Al Hirt, famed jazz trumpeter, will be in Memphis next week as a guest of Shelby County Mayor Bill Morris to investigate a possible permanent move here, Morris said. -- Hirt, who lived in Memphis in the 1940s, will visit the city Thursday through Saturday with an eye toward possibly using Memphis as a base for his performances. -- Morris said he was courting 'some degree of permanency' for Hirt in Memphis. Hirt recently shut down his famous nightclub in New Orleans' French Quarter, complaining of crime and other problems in the area. -- 'Al likes Memphis real well,' Morris said. 'He's going to take a look at some of the things that are happening here. We're going to show him the flavor, the example of great Memphis hospitality.' -- Some of that hospitality probably will include a visit to the Beale Street redevelopment project, which already has received commitments from entertainers Lou Rawls and Charlie Rich to open clubs there. Morris said Hirt and his party may visit The Peabody and a private home during their stay. -- Morris said hirt would be a 'great addition' to the Peabody's Skyway Room as a performer a few nights a week. Eventually, Morris said, he would like to see a national radio broadcast coming from the Skyway, similar to the one done during the big-band era. -- 'Al Hirt's name is known throughout the country,' Morris said. 'It could become a catalyst.'..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bloom, David

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Jazz Fare Is Soul Food for Trumpeter"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; music; Stamm, Marvin; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "...Stamm, whose family is in the clothing business here, is a graduate of Snowden Junior High School and Central High School. Interested in jazz since he was 16, the 42-year-old artist lives with his wife and two daughters in the small town of Purdys, N.Y., about 50 miles from New York City. He drives into the city 'whenever I have to work' - which is often. -- Stamm makes his living doing studio work and plays enough club dates to make a pretty good living , he said, giving him the freedom to play jazz without financial pressures. -- 'Having this circumstance allows me a tremendous amount of freedom in the music that I play, and in my own ability to do what I like to do best, rather than having to please club owners and managers,' he said. -- The freedom Stamm talks about is the freedom to play jazz without sacrificing improvisational creativity for what is commercially successful, what will sell in the record stores or draw the biggest crowds. -- Stamm describes true jazz as an American art form 'based strictly on improvisation. It takes on many forms and shades of coloring and many styles. -- What is commonly called fusion jazz today is 'crossover' music, according to Stamm. 'It doesn't have the basic ingredient to any degree of depth that the basic roots of jazz has had all these years. There is not a tremendous amount of improvisation.'..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peace, Shelia
