oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Four jazzmen to join for piano 'summit'"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: jazz; Mabern, Harold; music; Newborn, Phineas, Jr.; Thomas, Charles; Williams, James; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jazz is not a music readily identifiable with Memphis, as are blues, rock and roll and soul. Finding jazz in a local club requires patience and often the luck to be there on the right night. -- That's remarkable, considering the number of great players that have come out of Memphis: Phineas Newborn, Jr., his brother Calvin, Hank Crawford, Jamil Nasser, Jimmy Jones, Fred Ford, George Coleman, Frank Strozier... The existence of a Memphis jazz fraternity - though its members are spread around - can be seen on Harold Mabern's late-'60s album for Prestige, Workin' & Wailin'. His group on the record features George Coleman; the songs include 'Blues for Phineas' and 'Strozier's Mode.' -- An event next Sunday, Dec. 20, will focus considerable attention on the jazz heritage of this area as four pianists join forces for the 'Memphis Piano Summit': Newborn, Mabern, Charles Thomas and James Williams. -- The credentials are impressive. Newborn is recognized as perhaps the most creative pianist in contemporary jazz; Mabern has fronted his own groups and has played with Lee Morgan, George Benson and Freddie Hubbard; Williams has taught at Berklee College of Music in Boston and recently finished a long stint with Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers; Thomas has played with Mercer Ellington and is one of those musicians that other players are always talking about...."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Firestone Tire and Rubber Company Memphis Plant Collection Finding Aid
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: business; economy; Firestone Tire and Rubber Company; Firestone, Raymond C.; Frayser; industry; New Chicago; rubber;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Material in the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company Collection provides important information on the company that at one time was the largest manufacturer in Memphis, employing thousands of individuals working in a facility that covered several hundred acres in North Memphis. The parent company in Akron, Ohio, was founded in 1900 by Harvey S. Firestone, Sr., one of America's great business entrepreneurs. The Memphis Firestone plant was built in 1936 and incorporated the Murray Wood Products Company plant, which was owned by Fisher Body Corporation. This facility was the initial unit for the new Firestone tire manufacturing operation. Raymond C. Firestone, one of the founder's four sons, was transferred from California to head the operation of the Mid-South facility. The Memphis plant grew rapidly, soon out-producing its early goals, and the communities of Frayser and New Chicago were developed to provide homes near the Firestone operation for the company workforce. In 1956, the Firestone Company advertised its Memphis plant as the "largest single tire producing unit in the world on 35 acres of floor space, producing 1 out of every 17 tires manufactured in the U.S." The ad pointed out that the Memphis plant employed some 4, 000 men and women and contributed more than $25, 000, 000 annually to the local economy. Growth continued through the 60s and 70s, but the plant was forced to close in 1983. The collection includes one box of print materials and one large album of photographs, which depict all phases of tire manufacturing and production at the Memphis plant. In addition to the materials in this collection, the Memphis Information File contains more than one hundred newspaper clippings on the Firestone Company, and the Memphis Room Photograph Collection includes 34 photographs, many showing the initial 1936 construction. The Memphis Room also has bound copies of the company's annual reports from 1938 through 1973. This material provides an important historical record of the company's significant role in the economic history of Memphis. Materials in this collection were donated to the Public Library after the close-down phase of the Firestone plant had been completed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Collection processed by Patricia M. LaPointe and Joan Cannon
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Firestone Tire and Rubber Company Memphis Plant Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Wins Wings"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aviation; Harbin, Emma; 1920s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Memphis' newest woman flier is Mrs. J. C. Harbin, who already has won her laurels at swimming. She successfully passed the Department of Commerce's test for a private pilot's license at Memphis Airport Sunday. Mrs. Harbin 'soloed' in less time than the average male student."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Carnival Aviatrix"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aviation; Cotton Carnival; Harbin, Emma; Northrup, Harry E.; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Mrs. J. C. Harbin, well-known Memphis flier, who will take part in the program of the Cotton Carnival, is here depicted by Harry E. Northrup, local cartoonist. Mrs. Harbin will entertain the Carnival crowds with Immelman turns and other stunts."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "How Dizzy That Frog Must Be!"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aviation; Harbin, Emma; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Promised to a thousand admirers and trophy hunters, the little green frog showing white in the picture attached to the right pocket of the jacket worn by Mrs. Emma M. Harbin, the 'Dixie Eagle,' has looped more loops and spun more spins that any frog alive. -- Mrs. Harbin's luckpiece, that has accompanied her on stunting expeditions all over the country, will be with her tomorrow afternoon when she takes part in the first annual 'Fall Air Festival' sponsored by the Dixie Aviation Club at Municipal Airport. -- Her 'part' will consist of some of the most dangerous stunt flying on the program and including balloon bursting, twin ribbon cutting, bomb dropping, flying her place across the field on one wheel and her usual repertoire of single, double and triple inside loops, spins, Immelman turns and dare-devil serial acrobatics."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Hears Again" and "Will Take Plane Cure"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aviation; Harbin, Emma; hearing impairment; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two clippings: -- "Hears Again -- It was at a height of 5,000 feet that thears of Mrs. C. C. Bradbury, (above) 940 Nefler, 'popped' and her hearing came back. An airplane ride with Mrs. J. C. Harbin, Memphis aviatrix, restored Mrs. Bradbury's hearing after two years of almost total deafness. Now Lieut. E. F. Armour, of Fire Company 14, has decided to try Mrs. Harbin's aerial cure for his deafness. They will make the flight next week." -- "Will Take Plane Cure -- Lieut. Armour Hopes Hearing Will Be Restored After Flight -- Another Memphian who is hard-of-hearing, Lieut. E. F. Armour, of Fire Company 14, has decided to try an airplane ride in the hopes that altitude and motor roar will help him..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: two newspaper clippings, mounted, 2 x 7.25 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence between C.H.M. Dancy and Gen. J.W. Garth
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil War; correspondence; Alabama; Garth, J. W.; Dancy, C. M.; 1860s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: C.H.M. Dancy to General J. W. Garth. Dancy is writing to Garth to request his presence at a meeting in Fletcher, AL where locals will discuss "the reestablishing of the original state of things in the county and State." At the end, he makes a personal request for meal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dancy, C. H. M.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Delta Sigma Theta volunteers
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Delta Sigma Theta; sororities; volunteers; radio; West Tennessee Talking Library; libraries; Trammel, Rorie; portraits; WYPL; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From WYPL Radio: "We are pleased to honor WYPL volunteer reader Rorie Trammel (shown bottom row, right) -- Rorie was a second year students at Memphis State University in the fall of 1980 and in the pledge class for Delta Sigma Theta Sorority. As a pledge project, a group of 17 young ladies volunteered to read for the West Tennessee Talking Library (now WYPL) for one month. There are 16 of the ladies in the picture. -- The group is planning a reunion in 2012. We hope they will stop by for a visit and to see our progress after 31 years. Rorie was a volunteer on and off for a number of years after the class project and has been a permanent reader at WYPL since October 5, 2006. -- Thank you, Rorie!"
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: photocopy of color photo, 7.75 x 5.25 in.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hemphill School - Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hemphill Diesel Schools; insurance; commercial properties; Massachusetts Bonding and Insurance Company; A. E. Pipkin and Sons; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from J. A. Pipkin, an agent for the Massachusetts Bonding and Insurance Company, to G. M. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hemphill School - Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hemphill Diesel Schools; education; banking; finance; First National Bank of Memphis; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from William Mitchell, Vice President of The First National Bank of Memphis, to the State Department of Education in Nashville about Hemphill Schools, Inc.: "... Our friends have always maintained satisfactory bank balances with us, and all loans, which are supported by the guaranty of t he Technical Craft Corporation, Los Angeles, California, have been handled in a proper manner... It is our opinion that company is properly managed and enjoys good reputation."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mitchell, William

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Suffrage Rally
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Price, Hannah; portraits; suffrage; automobiles; women;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A portrait of three women and a man in a car with a banner that says “Votes for Women”. It seems plausible that this photo was taken during a suffrage rally. In addition, the name “Hannah Price” is written on the front and back of the photo, which suggests that one of the women in the car is Hannah Price, the president of the Morristown, TN, chapter of the State Equal Suffrage Association during 1911.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Collection donated by June Beasley Mann; Collection processed by Laura Fogarty
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The J. B. Mann Suffrage Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Count Magri, Lavinia Warren and Baron Magri
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Warren, Lavinia; Magri, Primo; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A portrait of three little people in formal dress. Based on the time period it seems likely that the photo’s subjects are Lavinia Warren, Count Primo Magri, and Baron Magri. Lavinia Warren was a famous circus performer who became one of the most well-known figures of the period when she married Charles Sherwood Stratton, also known as General Tom Thumb. Count Primo Magri was her second husband.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Collection donated by June Beasley Mann; Collection processed by Laura Fogarty
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The J. B. Mann Suffrage Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: W. C. Handy's Beale Street Blues
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; music; sheet music; Handy, W. C.; blues; Lee, George W.; jazz;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The cover of the sheet music to W. C. Handy's "Beale Street Blues." "Beale Street...Where the Blues Began" was published by Handy Brothers Music Co., Inc. The cover contains scenes reproduced by courtesy of the Commercial Appeal from the dedication of Handy Square on Beale, March 29, 1931. The picture in the upper left shows the crowd gathered in the square. The picture in the upper right shows W. C. Handy and Lt. George W. Lee in the car leading the parade. The picture in the lower left shows the parade on Beale Street. The picture in the lower right shows school children in floats.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Handy, W. C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: W. C. Handy Beale Street Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Concorde Lands in Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: airplanes; transportation; Memphis International Airport;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Video footage of Concorde landing in Memphis in 1979 during a promotional tour. From Richard Hoffman's notes: "The Concord [sic] landing at Memphis International Airport - Spring, 1979. This is the only landing of a Concord [sic] in Memphis, as far as I know. The plane was on a promotional tour and had not yet started commercial passenger service [in the United States]."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forrest Monument Association Minutes Book
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; statues;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Leather ledger book containing 157 pages of entries regarding the funding, design, execution, and installation of the Gen. N.B. Forrest equestrian statue in Forrest Park. -- Some pages were blank, missing from the binding, or were cut from the ledger. -- Only pages with entries, letters, or newspaper clippings attached were scanned. -- Note: Judge John Preston Young, the Monument Association Secretary, did not record minutes in the ledger in chronological order. Judge Young began recording minutes dating from 1894 to 1905, added 1905 newspaper clippings, skipped over many blank pages, and then started over again beginning with 1898 and ending with 1905.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: Ledger book, 157 pages, unbound, 8.25 in. x 13.75 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forrest Monument Association Cash Ledger Book
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; Niehaus, Charles H.; statues;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Leather ledger book containing 43 pages of entries pertaining to the funding for the design, execution, and installation of the Gen. N.B. Forrest equestrian statue in Forrest Park. -- Most of the pages were blank. -- Only pages with entries and notes attached were scanned. -- Note: James E. Beasley, Monument Association Treasurer, recorded entries in chronological order.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: Ledger book, 43 pages, bound, 8.25 in. x 13.75 in.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Helen Keller Inscription
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Keller, Helen; books;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two pages from a copy of Helen Keller's Journal, a book published by Doubleday, Doran & Company, Inc. in 1938. This copy bears an inscription from Helen Keller: "To the Memphis Woman's Club, whose beautiful message of appreciation put a happy zest into my work. Cordially yours, Helen Keller -- January 12th, 1942."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Charles Henry Niehaus and the Forrest Monument
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; Niehaus, Charles H.; statues;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a collection of letters, photographs, newspaper articles and entries made in the Forrest Monument Association Minutes Book, in chronological order, pertaining to the funding, design, execution, and installation of the Gen. N.B. Forrest equestrian statue in Forrest Park. The design phase began with the awarding of the contract to sculptor Charles Henry Niehaus in 1901. Niehaus's tireless effort to create a statue befitting the "Wizard of the Saddle" is a worthy story which unfolds in this collection. Some pages of the minutes book were missing or were cut from the book, so there will be gaps in time. This collection would not have been possible without the contributions of many individuals who cherish history and art.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Muska, Becky
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forrest Monument Addendum -- Revised working model
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; Niehaus, Charles H.; statues;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of the model at the Pink Palace Museum. When this model arrived at the Museum of the Confederacy in Richmond, VA, in 1911, King Phillip's tail was not attached so it could be crated and shipped. Charles Niehaus told Mrs. Janet (Norman V.) Randolph that sculptors in Richmond could easily attach the tail properly, but there is some damage to the tail. This model was insured.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forrest Monument Addendum -- United Daughters of the Confederacy General Convention Minutes 1911 and 1912
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; Niehaus, Charles H.; statues; United Daughters of the Confederacy;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1911 Minutes stated that Mrs. Virginia Frazer Boyle gifted the unpainted plaster equestrian model to the N.B. Forrest UCV. This was the model that Virginia's mother, Letitia Frazer claimed was given to her by Charles Niehaus. The 1912 Minutes stated that another working model of the Forrest monument was acquired for the Tennessee Room at the Museum of the Confederacy by Mrs. Baker. This model which was painted to resemble unweathered bronze was sent to Mrs. Janet (Norman V.) Randolph by Charles Niehaus.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Betty Luck, Librarian - UDC General Headquarters, Richmond, VA.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: United Daughters of the Confederacy library, Richmond, VA

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pictorial map of the East Buntyn neighborhood
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: maps; drawings; neighborhoods; country clubs; Southern Avenue; West Tennessee Normal College; Goodwyn Street; Greer Street; Highland Street;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The image shows the Memphis Country Club to the west and West Tennessee Normal College (now the University of Memphis) to the east. Labeled north-south streets are Goodwyn St., Greer St., Madeline St. (now Holmes St.), Alexander St., Reese St., Prescott St., Peachtree St. (now Ellsworth St.), and Highland St. East-west streets are Midland Ave. and Southern Ave. Messick High School and the Normal Railway Station are also represented. The drawing is signed "Bluff City Eng. Co. Memphis."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Audio - Memphis on NPR's Weekend Edition
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: radio; WKNO; National Civil Rights Museum; Herenton, W. W.; politics; race relations; Johnican, Minerva; Cody, W. J. Michael; Pyramid; Sides, Hampton; A. Schwab; Schwab, Abe; Burch, Lucius; Wolf River Society for the Prevention of Taking Oneself Too Seriously; Graceland; Presley, Elvis; Ardent Studios; music; Eric Gales Band;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Numerous topics related to Memphis are discussed during an episode of Weekend Edition, an NPR program. Starts with a journalist's persepctive on the state of the city. A story about the election of Willie Herenton includes the voices of community members calling in to local radio shows. Hampton Sides covers the new Pyramid. A reporter visits A. Schwab's store on Beale and speaks with proprietor Abe Schwab. A visit to Lucius Burch's Wolf River Society for the Prevention of Taking Oneself Too Seriously. A visit to Graceland. The brothers of the Eric Gales Band -- Manuel Gales (aka "Little Jimmy King"), Eric Gales and Eugene Gales -- record at Ardent Studios. Recorded off of WKNO, there are a few breaks in the original recording.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lanier, Robert A.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clarence Saunders Store No. 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: advertising; Saunders, Clarence; billboards; art; business; grocery stores;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An illustrated billboard, presumedly at the site where Memphis businessman Clarence Saunders was to build a new store. The cartoon refers to Saunders' having declared bankrupcy twice before: in 1923 with Piggly Wiggly, and 1930 with Clarence Saunders Sole Owner of My Name Stores.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: cotton; riverboats; steamboats;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Floating Mining Plant
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: boats; barges; mining;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: #1031 MS-Mining Plant -- Text on back: Freeport Sulphur Company's novel floating mining plant is shown being towed, with tugboats fore and aft, from construction headquarters to the new mine site at Bay St. Elaine, deep in the Louisiana marshlands. The plant will go into production in November to produce 2,000,000 gallons of superheated water a day for use in the Frasch method of mining salt dome sulphur deposits.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Talking Leaves: A Regional Focus - Episodes 3 and 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; writers; Govan, Christine Noble; Knight, Etheridge; Karpinski, Mary Helen; Frazier, Levi;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Talking Leaves program was a series of interviews with Tennessee regional writers which focus on the writer as a personality and unique artist working in a clearly defined locale. This clip includes two episodes. Episode 3 features Christine Noble Govan, interviewed by Mary Helen Karpinski in Chattanooga, Tennessee. The seventh episode features Etheridge Knight, interviewed by Levi Frazier in Bill's Twilight Lounge in Memphis. The Knight episode begins around 33:40.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Talking Leaves: A Regional Focus - Episodes 6 and 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; writers; Campbell, Will D.; Raines, Tom; Egerton, John; Karpinski, Mary Helen;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Talking Leaves program was a series of interviews with Tennessee regional writers which focus on the writer as a personality and unique artist working in a clearly defined locale. This clip includes two episodes. Episode 6 features Will Davis Campbell, interviewed by Tom Raines in Campbell's log cabin office near Nashville. Episode 5 (second on the recording) features journalist John Egerton, interviewed by Mary Helen Karpinski in Nashville, TN. The Egerton episode begins around 44:10.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Talking Leaves: A Regional Focus - Episodes 2 and 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; writers; Drake, Robert; Karpinski, Mary Helen; Scarbrough, George; Ripley, Tennessee;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Talking Leaves program was a series of interviews with Tennessee regional writers which focus on the writer as a personality and unique artist working in a clearly defined locale. This clip includes two episodes. Episode 2 features Robert Drake, interviewed by Mary Helen Karpinski in Ripley, Tennessee. Episode 1 (second on the recording) features poet and Polk County native George Scarbrough, interviewed by Mary Helen Karpinski. The Scarbrough episode begins around 41:20.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Talking Leaves: A Regional Focus - Episodes 4 and 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; writers; Marion, Jeff Daniel; Raines, Tom; Wallis, C. Lamar; Fowler, Ramsey; Gann, Dan;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Talking Leaves program was a series of interviews with Tennessee regional writers which focus on the writer as a personality and unique artist working in a clearly defined locale. This clip includes two episodes. Episode 4 features poet Jeff Daniel Marion, interviewed by Tom Raines in Dandridge, Tennessee. Episode 8 features an introduction by C. Lamar Wallis and an analysis and discussion of the Talking Leaves series, featuring Dr. Ramsey Fowler from Memphis State University and Dann Gann from the Literature Department of the Memphis/Shelby County Public Library & Information Center. The second episode begins around 48:30.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Forrest Monument Minutes Book missing pages
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Forrest monument; Forrest Park; Niehaus, Charles H.; statues;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Missing pages from the minutes book acquired by the contributor over 20 years ago from a Civil War relics dealer in Little Rock, AR. Page 9-10 entry dated August 9, 1898 concerns subscriptions for the monument fund drive. Page 11 entry dated January 15, 1901 mentions a letter from the Hon. Charles Seall of Rosedale, MS who suggested that the association ask prominent citizens in all the counties to help solicit subscriptions for the monument fund drive. Page 12 entry dated May 1, 1901 mentions removal of members for non-attendance and Gen. Gordon gave a report on the progress of the design phase of the monument.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Muska, Becky
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pearl Harbor
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Pearl Harbor; World War II; ships; U.S. Navy;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A cropped version of a National Archives photograph (80-G-32640). "View looking down 'Battleship Row' from Ford Island Naval Air Station, shortly after the Japanese torpedo plane attack. USS California (BB-44) is at left, listing to port after receiving two torpedo hits. In the center are USS Maryland (BB-46) with the capsized USS Oklahoma (BB-37) alongside. USS Neosho (AO-23) is at right, backing clear of the area. Most smoke is from USS Arizona (BB-39)." Caption from http://www.history.navy.mil/
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memoirs of John William McAfee, Sr. 1915-2001
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: civil rights; film; media; news;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John William ‘Bill’ McAfee, Sr. began his career in film as an assistant projectionist during the silent movie era and remained active through the medium’s various transformations. He played an interesting part in socio-history by screening films for Boss Crump’s chief censor, Lloyd T. Binford, and Elvis Presley. As a Navy serviceman, he secretly filmed Japanese beachheads for Marine Invasions. As a news cameraman, he worked with correspondents such as Dan Rather, Tom Jerrard, Don Farmer and Peter Jennings and interviewed and documented everything from W.C. Handy to the Civil Rights Movement. He also worked on motion pictures, most notably MGM’s Intruder in the Dust, where he enjoyed hanging out with William Faulkner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McAfee, John William

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cianciolo Theaters
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theaters; movies; film; buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Cianciolo theatres are shown together here as part of an ad in 1995 announcing the construction of a new theatre in Whitehaven Plaza. That theatre was never completed, but a Whitehaven Cinema was constructed in 1966 by General Cinema and was twinned in 1973. Instead of a new theatre in Whitehaven, the southernmost suburb, a theatre was opened in Frayser, the northernmost suburb." - Caption from Vincent Astor's book, Memphis Movie Theatres.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - President Obama at 2011 Booker T. Washington High School Graduation
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Booker T. Washington High School; Obama, Barack; presidents; education;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The WMC-TV Channel 5 broadcast from the 2011 Booker T. Washington High School graduation ceremonies, featuring commencement speaker President Barack Obama.

WMC-TV, Channel 5 Coverage of the President’s visit to Memphis and the 2011 Booker T. Washington High School Graduation (Commentators: Joe Birch and Ursula Madden) Graduation ceremony facilitated by Principal Alisha Kiner Cannon Center for the Performing Arts
00:35 – Presentation of Colors by the BTW Jr. ROTC. National Anthem performed by Shalonda Williams and Tecia Marshall. 03:55 – Processional of Class of 2011 08:05 – Entrance of President Obama 09:55 – Remarks by Salutatorian Vashti Taylor 12:30 – Paula Hollins sings class song, “I Am One” 16:30 – Remarks by Valedictorian Alexis Wilson 20:15 – Introduction of the Speaker by Christopher Dean 22:40 – Commencement Speaker, President Barack Obama 48:00 – Diplomas awarded 1:03:58 – Graduates adjust tassels and sing alma mater 1:06:00 – Remarks by Principal Alisha Kiner 1:07:50 – Obama departs 1:08:30 – Graduates exit 1:11:50 – Newsroom coverage with Andrew Douglas 1:14:00 – Footage of President with graduates before ceremony. 1:35:00 – President’s arrival at Air Force One. 2:04:10 – BTW’s video submission for the Race to the Top Challenge (cut off by Dr. Oz show)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bolton, Dickens & Co. Record of Slaves, 1856-1858
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: slavery; genealogy; Bolton, Wade; Bolton, Isaac; Dickens, Thomas;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title page includes: "Ellis, William D., ALS to Z. B. Oakes (Dated October 6, 1975, Misc. Mss. Ellis); Davis, H. Winter, ALS to William Pitt Fessenden (Dated February 3, 1863. Misc. Mss. Davis)." -- Summary of Preface and Introduction: Bolton, Dickens & Company was the largest of the slave dealing businesses in Memphis as of 1860. The firm, which also sold cotton, had business houses in Richmond, Vicksburg, Mobile, Charleston, Lexington, Jefferson City and in Memphis - first at the corner of Adams and Main, and later on Adams between Second and Third. Brothers Wade and Isaac Bolton were in business together before Thomas Dickens became a partner, but the firm ran into legal and financial troubles that led to its ultimate decline. In 1857, Isaac Bolton shot and killed a Kentucky slave dealer. Although Bolton was eventually acquitted, the legal bill of $100,000 was paid from the company account, leading to more lawsuits and battles within the firm. Isaac died in 1864 and Wade was killed by partner Thomas Dickens on July 23, 1869. -- Pages 1-38 are a day-to-day accounting by Isaac Bolton for the months of March and April 1865. Pages 39-79 list the names of slaves, purchase prices, etc. Pages 80-91 include entries for sale of slaves. Pages 92-99 are transcriptions of correspondence and the last section includes newspaper articles and advertisements.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Transcribed and Compiled by Shirley C. Neely
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2014, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Memphis Sounds with George Klein - Episode #1
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; Klein, George; music; Alexander, James; Bar-Kays; McCormack, John "Bad Dog"; radio; Samudio, Sam "The Sham"; Dickinson, Jim;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Klein and James Alexander of the Bar-Kays discuss NARAS and the state of the Memphis music scene, and an archival clip of the Bar-Kays performing is shown. Sam the Sham discusses his family, family name, and the beginnings of The Pharoahs. "Bad Dog" McCormack discusses his career as a comedian and as a DJ at Rock 103. Jim Dickinson tells of growing up in the Memphis music scene.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; Klein, George; music; Presley, Elvis; Graceland; Soden, Jack; Davis, Richard; Leigh, Suzanna; Fontana, D. J.; Moore, Scotty; Sun Studio; Nichopoulos, George;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Memphis Sounds with George Klein - Episode #23
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: television; Klein, George; music; Phillips, Johnny; Samudio, Sam "The Sham"; Flinn, George; Esperian, Kallen; Hayes, Isaac;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Klein and Johnny Phillips discuss Select-O-Hits, Sam Phillips, and Jerry Lee Lewis. Sam The Sham tells about his biggest hit. Dr. George Flinn discusses his history in radio. Soprano Kallen Esperian tells of her personal history in opera and Memphis. Isaac Hayes details his early days. Includes a clip of The Buckinghams performing "Kind of a Drag."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Sewerage of Memphis, U.S.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: sewers; sewer system; sanitation; infrastructure; public works; maps;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On September 23, 1880, George E. Waring, Jr. presented his paper to the Sanitary Institute of Great Britain's 1880 meeting. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Deputies' Association Chief Talks With Picketers"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1978 Police and Fire strike; strikes; Shelby County Sheriff; police; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Richard L. Pinner, president of the Shelby County Sheriffs' Association, far right, talks with picketing policemen at Police Headquarters downtown. Sheriffs' deputies did not cross picket lines set up this morning at the deputies' substation at 5705 Shelby Oaks Drive. However, deputies continued to work when non-union officers crossed the lines and brought cars and equipment to the officers."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gurner, Jack

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Striking Firemen Picket Sanitation Substation"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1978 Police and Fire strike; strikes; AFSCME; fire department; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Some 1,100 sanitation workers, members of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, honored the firefighters' picket lines and refused to report for work today. AFSCME officials said the workers will continue to honor the pickets and predicted more city and county employees will be affected as the firefighters increase their pickets. These workers were at the substation on Democrat Road."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Captain Luke J. Weathers and Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, Jr.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Weathers, Luke, Jr.; Davis, Benjamin O., Jr.; Tuskegee Airmen; military; pilots; portraits; World War II;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. return [sic] to Tuskegee Army Air Field - Colonel Davis return [sic] to TAAF to celebrate VE Day, August 18, 1945. He was introduced by Capt. Luke J. Weathers who served under his command in the 332nd Fighter Group. Platform guest [sic] left to right were Colonel Dibble, CO Tuskegee VA Hospital, Colonel Noel F. Parrish, CO TAAF, Capt. Weathers, Colonel Davis, Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, President of Tuskegee Institute, LTC Richard C. Cummings, Post Surgeon, and Major Harold C. Magoon, Master of Ceromony [sic]."
